data.name: Computer problem series #3: Hacha software split
data.description:
Your task is to determine the outputs of the Hacha Software. Hacha (Axe in spanish) is used to slice a file in small parts in order to be able to send it in an email, save it in small devices, etc. 

The function will receive a file (dictionary) and a size then you will have create a code to divide the original file in smaller parts of the size given and with their own names based in the original file. 

If you are going to separate a file named `filename.ext` in two, those files will be named: `filename.ext.1` and `filename.ext.2`. If you are going to create more than 9 files, all the new file names should have the same lenght with leading zeros: `filename.ext.01`, `filename.ext.02`, ..., `filename.ext.10`. The same concept applies to 100, 1000, etc files. 

At least the first n-1 files should have the same size (the one given to the function) and be as big as possible, only the later could have a smaller size. 

If the file data is empty you should return an empty array `[]`

### Input:

* file: (dictionary) 
  * name (string)
  * data (string))
* size of the output files (integer)

### Output: 

* List of dictionaries

### Examples: 

1. Basic case

```
file = {"name": "ex.py", "data": "abcdefghijkl"}
size = 6

hacha(file, size) -> [{"name": "ex.py.1", "data": "abcdef"}, {"name": "ex.py.2", "data": "ghijkl"}]
```

2. More than 9 files

As you can see the new names add `.X` to the original file name. You should add the minimun number of characters that will be needed. In order to name 10, 100, 1000, etc. files, 2, 3 of 4 characters will be needed at the end. 

```
file = {"name": "ex.py", "data": "1234567890"}
size = 1

hacha(file, size) -> [{"name": "ex.py.01", "data": "1"}, ... {"name": "ex.py.10", "data": "0"}]
```

3. Output size is not multiple of file size

Every file should have the same size except for the last. 

```
file = {"name": "ex.py", "data": "12345678"}
size = 3

hacha(file, size) -> [{"name": "ex.py.1", "data": "123"}, {"name": "ex.py.2", "data": "456"}, {"name": "ex.py.3", "data": "78"}]
```

4. Empty data

In this case an empty array should be returned. 

```
file = {"name": "ex.py", "data": ""}
size = 3

hacha(file, size) -> []
```

Do not expect any invalid inputs. 

### Specifications: 
```
5 <= len(name) <= 25
0 <= len(data) <= 100000
0 < size <= 100
```
